review_title: Chilled out culture and employees but tech processes are behind industry standards
job_title: Lead Product Owner in Beaverton, OR
pros: I work in the Global Technology group. Easy going, forgiving culture. Plenty of head count redundancy. Work I would do by myself at my former employer is done by 4-5 heads at Nike. Makes for great work life balance. Just getting your job done leads to kudos - feels like you get a medal for showing up. Even better if you can talk up your work and make the right noises in front of upper management.
cons: Processes and tools not up to industry standards. Practices like Agile Scrum that I had adopted 10 years ago are adopted in name only. No rigor in processes leading to waste. Teams work in silos and may or may not bring in other teams impacted by a solution or new process - you are left to 'find out' or figure it out. No structures exist for a robust cross team sharing of pertinent information. Teams staffed by large number of contract workers cannot be bothered to share across teams. Leads to design misses/poorly designed solutions and production defects.

pros: There are some decent benefits comparable to what most other blue chip companies will offer. The campus and gyms are nice.
cons: If you enjoy writing and shipping value through software avoid Global Technology, particularly Enterprise Data & Analytics, at all costs. Most of the department is a sinkhole of money, with constant political battles at the director/vp level that ensure nothing of value is ever actually shipped. The shocking attrition of talent over the last couple years have left the organization with "senior" leaders and individual contributors who simply do not know what they're doing. For your own sanity and mental health, avoid any technology role at this company like the plague.

review_title: Experience of a lifetime, but soul draining at the same time
pros:
Amazing people-more good than bad. A culture that does value individuality...as long as you're a team player. Casual, but faced paced environment, There's no place like Nike in many ways.
Part of the "good old days" where Nike celebrated it's people and rewarded hard work.
cons:
People aren't set up to be great leaders and are often promoted because "who they know" and how they manage up, even if Nike tried to change that in light of bad PR a few years ago. 
Nike is SO big it often gets in it's own way, inefficient processes and the matrixed environment slow things down so much. Sometimes you have to socialize things with 10 directors just to move forward to the next step, and by then you've either lost funding or there's a new priority out, so you just wasted you're time. 
Extremely competitive. 
Every few years, senior leadership changes so much that many priorities and process shift completely, just as you're finally getting used to one way of operating. That is exhausting and you can never feel fully on top of it all as often times, you're stretched thin and so is your team.

pros: The cafeteria food was good. At the campus I worked at, we were able to wind down when work was completed early. The discount was okay.
cons: Okay. So I've worked for Nike for almost 3 years in total. Some time I was a contractor and the other time I was a full time employee through the company. As a contractor we were treated horribly and Nike was seen to be a carrot sticks dangling in front of us. I became full time (after leaving my contracting position and applying online) and being employed with Nike was almost identical to being a contractor. Of course there's perks like... insurance. And actually being treated a bit more like a human. BUT! The managers all have issues. They treat the ones that don't do any work like shining stars. People never went into work and the only ones that did show were the contractors. Until it was time to lay them off without notice of course. And the people that did work hard got scrutinized for the smallest things because they were seen as the ones keeping the whole facade together. Gossip was horrible. The managers went out of their way to subtlety intimidate their employees. Competition was ridiculous because...like mentioned...favoritism was every where. And nobody was held accountable when they'd miss work for say 2 weeks and come in on a random day. Because the managers like them. It was hell. Also the trainers almost seemed like they were paid to keep people away. All in all Nike (the one I was employed with. Memphis TN) is a group mindset thing. If they like you and you belong I'm happy for you. But don't get surprised if your mysteriously get fired or someone tries to lie on you. I've heard it one too many times. Hey but give it a shot.

job_title: Senior Data Scientist in Portland, OR
pros: Work-life balance is there, you can truly work 40 hours a week or less and still succeed. Summer hours are great, benefits are great, 401k matching is awesome. This is the perfect place to finish your career and coast into retirement. Also, looks great on your resume if you are early-career.
cons: Duplicate work. The business has tension between "buy" vs. "build" and often has external vendors (or recently-acquired startups) competing against internal teams to build solutions. Vendors often win, which can be demoralizing for FTEs. Lots of work gets abandoned. Internal teams need to dedicate a lot of bandwidth to selling their work rather than doing their work. Huge organizational complexity. Death by meetings. So many meetings.

review_title: Nike - great work culture, lacking employee recognition and growth
pros: Nice employee benefits (45% discount), big campus, open gym, able to do charity through their platform. Great life and work balance. Ability to work from home and unlimited vacation days.
cons: Easy to get stuck in one position. They speak a lot about diversity and inclusivity, but actions do not reflect that. They are not willing to invest in the employee. Recognition and reward of hard work is to a minimum. Salary increases do not depend on employee performance rating. Internal opportunities run on overqualified members. Managers are not hold accountable for team stagnation and lack courage. Each 2-4 years a reorganisation happens, where managerial positions are quite easily demoted. Changes take month to implement which brings a lot of confusion.

review_title: Hard to get in, harder to move around
pros: There are some great people working here, and I believe in the leadership plan to sell more directly to consumers. Pre-covid we had some really nice on-campus events including free food and free drinks. Love the majority of the political stances the company projects through marketing, and the benefits the company has provided throughout the Covid pandemic including a lot of emotional support, vaccination opportunities, and paying retail employees around the world while all stores were closed to name a few. We now have free access to the gyms on campus and the group exercise classes and the campus, if you get located on it, is nice and serene. The occasional access to top professional athletes in all hands meetings, etc. is a very unique perk to Nike. I once got to attend a 30-person meet and greet with Brandi Chastain and asked her a couple of questions and a photo opp during the Women's World Cup. Very cool.
cons: I joined Nike with the promise to navigate my career here, with the options to gain experience in Europe, China, etc. The new changes that HR has implemented has COMPLETELY erased any advantage employees have to move to a new role. It's exactly the same as it is for people outside of Nike trying to get in. And I'm told that promotions are not a thing at all unless you start managing people or something else that drastically changes your role. I work in the technology org and there's no wonder Nike is losing tech folks right and left with the new return to campus hybrid model. When I started a couple of years ago, working from home was not supported AT ALL. It took a pandemic to prove to Nike that office workers could be productive remotely. Thankfully that has spurred a plan to allow employees to work from home UP TO 2 days a week. LOL Good luck keeping your top talent with that decision. I am on a user experience team that focuses on employee-facing digital tools and we can't get a foothold in the SDLC. UX is in it's infant stages for digital employee experiences. And the matrix of siloes here is insanely complex, it's a wonder we get anything done here.

job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Grand Prairie, TX
pros: I love Nike, I love the company, the history, and what the brand itself represent and stand for. I can say that they certainly do care about their staff and they try and give you as many resources to help you and they are very understanding of work/life balance. It's not the job that's hard, as a matter of fact, the job itself isn't hard at all and can sometimes pose as fun, depending on the day and crowd at the store.
cons: Management can either make or break your experience. Our head coach is amazing, she made her expectations for Nike employees very clear since day 1 and she upholds those values and standards. With that being said, some of the Head Coaches sometimes may not be on the same page when it comes to operations and rules or guidelines. Managers may be understanding of one situation, while head coaches lack proper communication and understanding of that same situation. It's a great job don't get me wrong, but head coaches perform very little to none in their day to day shifts and often aren't able to modify how they coach individual employees.
